title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" designates amounts for the reduction of public debt under Subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes a new part titled "DESIGNATION FOR REDUCTION OF PUBLIC DEBT" with section 6097 outlining the designation process. Every individual with adjusted income tax liability can designate up to 10% to reduce public debt when filing their tax return. The term 'adjusted income tax liability' refers to income tax liability reduced by any designated amount for the Presidential Election Campaign Fund. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts in Subchapter A. Part IX. Designation for reduction of public debt. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DEBT REDUCTION TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding section 9512 for the Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to pay off federal government obligations included in the public debt. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are appropriated to the Trust Fund, and any obligations paid with Trust Fund amounts are canceled and retired. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States is used to pay off federal government obligations in the public debt. Any obligations paid with Trust Fund amounts are canceled and retired, and cannot be reissued. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for the subchapter. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations in the public debt. Amendments made by this section apply to amounts received after the enactment of the Act. A new section is added for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration is required within 15 days after Congress adjourns, equivalent to the estimated aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code for the last taxable year. This sequestration is modified by any reductions in discretionary spending and changes in the deficit from the baseline amount. The legislation mandates reductions in discretionary spending limits and net deficit changes from baseline amounts. All accounts of the United States must be reduced by a calculated dollar amount to achieve these reductions permanently, with some accounts exempt from this requirement. The legislation mandates reductions in discretionary spending limits and net deficit changes from baseline amounts. All accounts of the United States must be reduced by a calculated dollar amount to achieve these reductions permanently, with some accounts exempt from this requirement, such as benefits payable under the Social Security Act and certain specified accounts like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation funds. The legislation mandates reductions in discretionary spending limits and net deficit changes from baseline amounts. Certain accounts are exempt from reductions, including those of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation funds. Amendments are made to Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 regarding reports to Congress. Amendments to Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 require reports to Congress on income tax estimates and sequestration to reduce public debt. New provisions include setting forth estimates for designated amounts under specific sections. Amendments to Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 now require reports to Congress on income tax estimates and sequestration to reduce public debt. The new provisions include setting forth estimates for designated amounts under specific sections, such as the aggregate amount designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the sequestration percentage necessary to achieve the required reduction in accounts under section 253A(b). Amendments to Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 now require reports to Congress on income tax estimates and sequestration to reduce public debt. The amendments include setting forth estimates for designated amounts under specific sections and the sequestration percentage necessary to achieve the required reduction in accounts. The effective date of these amendments is not subject to the expiration date set forth in the Act. The amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 now require a report on public debt taxation designation by May 1. The effective date of these amendments does not expire, but they will cease to have any effect after the first fiscal year without public debt.
